titleproper.value: Guide to the Collection of Soviet Union Photograph Albums and Photographs <num>PHOTOS.286</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-09-14T20:20:39</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Collection of Soviet Union Photograph Albums and Photographs

extent.value: in 1 manuscript box and 2 oversize flat boxes.

abstract.value: The Collection of Soviet Union Photograph Albums and Photographs contains two untitled photograph albums and photographs depicting activities in the Soviet Union and led by the Soviet state during the 1930s and 1940s.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Collection of Soviet Union Photograph Albums and Photographs; PHOTOS 286; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
The provenance of this collection is unknown. There is no accession record associated with this collection.

The Tamiment Library, a special collection documenting the history of United States labor, radicalism, and progressive social action, accumulated this artificial collection of photographs and photograph albums depicting activities of the Soviet Union.

The Collection of Soviet Union Photograph Albums and Photographs contains two untitled photograph albums and photographs depicting activities in the Soviet Union and led by the Soviet state during the 1930s and 1940s. One photograph album includes photographs of large-scale construction and city planning projects in the Soviet Union, likely during the Joseph Stalin era in the 1930s or 1940s.  The other photograph album contains photographs from the U.S.S.R. Conference for Peace held in Moscow in August 1949.  All photographs include English-language captions.  The inside front cover of the album contains a sticker with the emblem of the Ernest C. Ropes Memorial Library at the American Russian Institute and signature of Harlow Shapley.  Additionally, there are photographs from the 1937 Soviet film "Lenin in October". Small photographs are mostly 5" x 7." Large photographs are mostly 9" x 11" and have "MADE IN THE USSR" inscribed in the lower righthand corner.  There are also photograph negatives.
